trial_identification.studytitle: Diabetes and antenatal milk expressing (DAME) : a randomised controlled trial.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Investigation of the effect of antenatal milk expressing on babies of women with diabetes in pregnancy compared to the outcomes of babies of women with diabetes in pregnancy receiving standard care

conditions.healthcondition: Neonatal admission to Special and Intensive care, ,

interventions.interventions: Women with diabetes in pregnancy who are intending to breastfeed will commence twice daily antenatal milk expressing from 36 weeks gestation until birth.
interventions.comparator: Women with diabetes in pregnancy who are intending to breastfeed will receive usual care. In usual care women are not advised to commence expressing breast milk antenatally.

primaryOutcome.outcome: To establish whether the practice of antenatal breast milk expressing from 36 weeks gestation for women with diabetes in pregnancy increases the proportion of infants who require admission to the special or intensive care nursery compared with infants of women with diabetes in pregnancy receiving standard care (30% vs 20%).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Admission during the hospital stay following birth - data from medical record

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To establish whether the practice of antenatal breast milk expressing from 36 weeks gestation for women with diabetes in pregnancy increases the proportion of of infants receiving exclusive breast milk at three months of age compared with infants of women with diabetes in pregnancy receiving standard care (52% vs 40%).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Three months postpartum by telephone interview

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To establish whether the practice of antenatal breast milk expressing from 36 weeks gestation for women with diabetes in pregnancy increases the proportion of of infants receiving exclusive breast milk during the hospital stay after birth compared with infants of women with diabetes in pregnancy receiving standard care (37% vs 25%).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Admission during the hospital stay following birth - data from medical record

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To establish whether the practice of antenatal breast milk expressing from 36 weeks gestation for women with diabetes in pregnancy decreases the mean gestation at birth compared with infants of women with diabetes in pregnancy receiving standard care (37 weeks vs 38 weeks).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Collected from the medical record following birth

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Any woman with pre-existing or gestational diabetes; between 34 and 36 weeks gestation; with a singleton pregnancy in a cephalic presentation; attending the study sites for pregnancy care as a public patient; planning to breastfeed and able to speak , read and write in English
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Women -any history of antepartum haemorrhage, or placenta praevia -an unknown or classical caesarean section scar or more than one lower uterine segment caesarean section scar -any suspicion of fetal compromise - a known fetal abnormality.

trial_design.concealment: Computerised random number generator will be accessed by computer to ascertain the woman's allocation
trial_design.designfeatures: Data abstarction for the primary outcome will be blinded to group allocation. Medical records which will be seen by care providers will note study participation but not trial arm. Women (participants) can not be blinded to allocation.

recruitment.hospital: Monash Medical Centre - Clayton campus - Clayton
Barwon Health - Geelong Hospital campus - Geelong

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Judith Lumley Centre, La Trobe University

fundingsource.fundingname: National Health and Medical Research Council, Australia
fundingsource.fundingaddress: National Health and Medical Research Council GPO Box 1421 Canberra ACT 2601

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
Infants of women with diabetes in pregnancy have an increased risk of low blood sugar and other complications after birth and of developing diabetes and being obese later in life. Many maternity providers encourage these women to express breast milk before birth to have it available if the infant needs supplementary feeding.
Evidence for this practice is lacking so we are planning the first study exploring the safety and effectiveness of antenatal expression of breast milk in late pregnancy for women with diabetes in pregnancy.
ethicsAndSummary.publication:
Forster DA, Jacobs S, Amir LH, et al. Safety and efficacy of antenatal milk expressing for women with diabetes in pregnancy: protocol for a randomised controlled trial. BMJ Open 2014;4:e006571. doi:10.1136/bmjopen-2014-006571
Forster DA, Moorhead AM, Jacobs SE, ... Amir LH. Advising women with diabetes in pregnancy to express breastmilk in late pregnancy (Diabetes and Antenatal Milk Expressing [DAME]): a multicentre, unblinded, randomised controlled trial. The Lancet. 2017 Jun 3;389(10085):2204-2213. doi: 10.1016/S0140-6736(17)31373-9
